name: The Sarojin

reviews.title: Relaxing holiday
reviews.text: Just wanted to add to what others have been saying about this hotel and provide our experience as a counterpoint to some recently posted reviews.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed here for 10 nights and found plenty do to and enjoy. We had booked a garden suite and we were upgraded, on arrival to a Sarojin suite and we were very impressed by the room. We had a lovely open outlook over the resort and out to sea. The room was very spacious with large outdoor and indoor baths, huge living room and all the extras you'd expect for a 5 star. Nice touches included a sarong and wicker beach bag. The room was spotlessly clean, our only complaint was the indoor bath was badly eroded and rough to bathe in.
reviews.title: loved our short stay at The Sarojin

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The restaurants were busy every night with a good atmosphere. There was such a variety on the menus there was no need to eat elsewhere. We had planned on trying one or two of the restaurants on the beach but did not get round to it as we enjoyed the hotel food so much. I have been to Thailand many times and I would have to agree with other's who have posted on here, the Thai food at The Edge is excellent and as good as any I've tasted. We found the food good value but the wine was expensive, as it is throughout Thailand. The food at The Ficus is very good too. We ate outside and had tiny visitors in the shape of frogs coming to visit from the lily pond. Theme nights were also excellent, although the Asian buffet not quite as good as the beach or Thai cultural night buffets.
reviews.title: Fantastic relaxing Hotel

likes.liked: — The rooms were out of this world!!!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Our trip to the Similan Islands was excellent and although it was pricey (£100 a head) it was a highlight our our stay. Fantastic snorkelling and swimming. Crystal clear water and powdery white sand. The journey took an hour and the sea was very calm. I would reccomend this trip for socialising with fellow guests. The lunch was set up for us on an island under the trees and was delicious.

reviews.title: World class Sarojin

likes.disliked: — Price of dining relative to outside hotel

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We had the privilege to stay for 10 days at the Sarojin. We enjoyed that, but it could have been in London (except the scenery!). A place for people who want to have european style in Thailand. I know comparing is always a knife with two sides, but I liked much better the Anantara at Samui, which felt to me much more "authentic". But again this is only about preference. The staff was helpful but sometimes due to language barriers a bit helpless. Our room was very good, food above average but expensive (european prices). Beach is cool, I was happy that the Sarojin was a bit off, so you are at a place where you can chill out.To get to Khao Lak you can easily hire a scooter (do not drive during night times unless you are familiar with the road conditions and the traffic).
reviews.title: Boutique Hotel for Europeans?

reviews.title: Pure indulgence!

likes.disliked: — stepping on one of the gorgeous tiny frogs that were everywhere!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: There were numerous small touches that individually perhaps don't sound like much but I think illustrate the fantastic way guests are treated. When being transferred to the hotel our driver stopped off (unprompted) at a couple of temples and took the time to show us around, when we arrived at the hotel my wife was presented with a bouquet of flowers and we were given about three cups of tea and a complimentary 30 minute massage before checking in, the bed had the words "Happy Honeymoon" spelled out in petals, the management lay on a cocktail party every Tuesday in order to personally meet their guests, mountain bikes and watersports equipment are freely available for guests to use as they wish, they have a dedicated "Imagineer" who will do his best to arrange anything you could possibly want and so on and so on......
reviews.title: Absolute relaxation

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: What can be said that hasn’t been said before? As the last reviewer says, you get what you pay for. For those people who booked daytrips in town instead of at the hotel you certainly missed out on an absolute treat even if it does come at a price. A private dinner on the beach is a magical experience and a daytrip aboard the Lady Sarojin to the Similan islands was one of the nicest days I have ever spent thanks to fantastic staff who were on hand with fresh towels, champagne, took my girlfriend by the hand when they saw she was nervous when snorkeling and presented a great lunch on the beach. Other boats we saw from town had a lot of people on them and I’ll guarantee that they weren’t pampered like we were. Another daytrip saw us have lunch for two on the riverbank after taking a pleat boat in Lam Ru national park. We thought we were going to have lunch next to a waterfall but the location was moved once they discovered that there were a lot of people at the waterfall – a nice touch to keep the trip exclusive.
reviews.title: One of the best

likes.liked: — Lovely contempory design, good use of space and a fabulous bathroom

reviews.text: For those complaining about the price of wine, search the list and there is reasonable value to be found, especially for those of us used to paying London restaurant prices. You need to realise that import duties on wines and spirits are exceptionally high (to the point that the EU are currently seeking to get them lowered)
reviews.title: You get what you pay for: The Best

likes.liked: — Staff. Design. Attention to details. Bath product. Food. Service.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Service is a very strong point, the staff aren’t afraid to engage in conversation with guests as I have seen at some other luxury hotels, beach service was efficient and they were always able to find you a shady spot somewhere on the beach even if it did mean sitting under a tree with the waves lapping underneath your lounger!
reviews.title: I’m so happy that we chose Sarojin !

likes.disliked: — Lack of chez-longes on the beach when the hotel is full.But this is not a Sarojin's fault, but mostly of people who keeps them beasy all day after leaving the beach

reviews.text: The cocktail party is a lovely way to get to meet Kate and Andrew Kemp who made time to talk to guests well over an hour after the scheduled end of the party and they are genuinely interested in hearing your opinions. Without going into detail it is clear from the little speech that Andrew gives that they genuinely care for their guests way beyond the hotel boundaries

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I don't usually get around to writing reviews despite being a compulsive reader of them pre-holiday. However, having just seen the two recent, unfavourable, reviews of the Sarojin I feel compelled to add my comments!
reviews.title: Amazing - totally disagree with two previous reviews!
Not Good Enough Despite alll the Reviews
reviews.text: We had two amazing weeks (15 nights) at the Sarojin and foud it impossible to fault. We wanted somewhere peaceful and relaxing where we could enjoy some good food, beautiful surroundings and bascially be away from it all. It more than met our expectations.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I guess food is incredibly subjective but I am amazed to read any negative reviews about the quality of food, particularly in Ficus (the international restaurant). We thought it was some of the best we've ever had (and I'm a reasonably frequent visitor of good resaturants and hotels in the UK and overseas). Where service is concerned we thought the staff at the Sarojin were amazingly helpful - from the top down. We met the General Manager and her deputy on several occassions, as well as meeting the owners and all department heads throughout our stay and at the weekly drinks reception (a very nice and much appreciated touch). The waiting staff and those who cleaned our room were, without exception, really helpful, polite and efficient. We got to know some of them quite well and they were all a delight to deal with!
reviews.title: Didn't Live Up To Expectations

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The only problem I had with the entire holiday was a less than satisfactory Gin Fizz (hardly of life changing importance) and even that was resolved in true Sarojin style. Plah (?) who managed The Edge restaurant found me on the beach the next day to apologise and to offer us complimentary cocktails.
reviews.title: Terrible - Avoid this hotel

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: If you are looking for a kind of Thai pastiche (thatched cottages et al) then perhaps the Sarojin won't be your kind of thing. However, I think its contemporary styling worked really well (it was designed, I believe, by the same architect as the W Hotels). The grounds are stunning and looked magical at night. My one piece of advice (if you like the sun) would be to ask for a suite on the sunny side of the grounds.
reviews.title: Fantastic Honeymoon Hotel & Desitination

description: Award winning luxurious boutique beach resort, just 55 minutes from Phuket on a stunning, secluded white sand beach in Khao Lak. Exceptional personal services, top class facilities. Ideal for couples, romantic breaks, honeymoons, weddings and adult family groups. Designed in a contemporary Asian style with just 56 luxurious guest residences. Wide range of activities and facilities – cruise on a luxury boat, jungle adventures complete with champagne, glimpse authentic Thai local life in association with responsible and sustainable tourism commitment, rejuvenating spa massages lulled by the sounds of the Andaman sea, Thai cooking classes, lazy gourmet lunches, romantic diners on a secluded beach or by a candlelit jungle waterfall …the limits are only your imagination. No children under 10 years permitted to stay.
